While many people critiques this game for being buggy and the constant need to pay to progress well I find it quite a good MMO for a massive Star Trek fan.The game itself does have some bugs or mission breaking problems but you can restart all missions and generally it works the 2nd time, also regarding pay to progress yes when you reach Max level you need to pay $$$ to get a good ship and gear or if you have time you can earn Dilithiam (one of the ingame currencies) that you can sell for Zen (The real money currency)I have played well over 400 hours so far (And 100 since I moved to playing this on steam) and I have spent about $40 of real money on it, that money was used to but extra character slots to create a few Alts to do Missions to get extra Dilithium.Pro's: * Very Good story missions* The new Delta recruit system rewards you for making new characters* Voices from various Star Trek actors* Totally free to play if you have the patience* Pick up and play if you have an hour to kill you can hop in have a go at a few events and log off* Great graphics for an older game that will run on most systems* Event - New events are added all the time* Constant update: New missions are added all the time* Loads of classic Star Trek areas to exploreCons:* OK Bugs some missions are bugged which you can bypass * Bridge Officers (Power) have a tenancy to reset if you switch ships which means you need to reset them* A few features that seems to be there but abandoned (Gold pressed latinum store) would be nice to have expanded or at least updated* Queues for some PVP and PVE events can take to long due to lack of people not max level participating (XP rewards boost needed)So all in all it is worth getting and giving this game a go if you like star trek at all

Playing this game for over a year now, never spended any real money on it. it has a f2p model where all content is available for free. On the other hand if you want to buy something from the zen store, it can be very expensive.I had a lot of fun with this game so I recommend it.Pros:+ dont have to spend real money+ doesn't have a steep learning curve+ good community+ huge amount of content+ frequently updatedCons:- mediocre voice acting- monotonous missions sometimes- storylines are not that interesting- a lot of grinding Final score: 8/10

Star Trek online is a spectacular game. With that being said there is alot to do in game. The Quests and instances make you feel very immersed into the star trek universe. My only grip with this game as it can get complicated, there is somewhat of a learning curve and it can be overwhelming to some players. Over all this game is well done and it does a good job connecting all elements of every star trek series. Id say if you are a star trek fan you cant go wrong. If you like complicated yet dynamic space exploration games youll like this game as well. Communitys however are a different story, it is hard for me to find americans that I can group up with. Either way its a good game in an over saturated MMO market, so it kind of makes this a diamond in the rough.

An all around good game in many ways. First off you have three factions, all with at least a few races in each. Both ground and space combat are solid however space combat is easily the better of the two. There is of course the Federation, the Klingons, and the newest faction which are the Romulans.The Romulans have a story of liberation and resistance against a nearly rogue sect of the now shattered Romulan Star Empire. You fly warbirds which at each new rank grant you a new ability only usable on warbirds. All of them can cloak and a later version can even split into two.The downfall of the Romulans in my eye is that they have no great massive ship of their own. I find the Ha'apax Advanced Warbird a bit lacking in that department. And even though you are in fact forced to join either the Federation or Klingons you cannot actually gain access to their T4 and higher ships. So I must recommend a mightier faction, one of glory and honor. The Klingon Empire.The Klingon story is far more diverse and even includes a small portion of the Romulan story, even including the Romulan end mission around lv32. The story ranges from house rivalries and betrayals to the return of Klingon enemies from ancient lore among other interesting developments. The Klingons are a faction with many mighty ships designed for head-on combat that have hull strength only rivaled by ships you'd have to spend $150 opening gambling boxes to get your hands on. And this does not even diminish their offensive capabilities as their greatest ship is a carrier armed just as well as any warship.The Fedration offers little that can compare to the might of the Klingon Empire. Their ships seem to be designed around a doctrine of agility as many of their ships are far smaller but probably just as effective in combat if used properly.There is also a system for crew missions, where you deploy your crew to go do things like sacking a colony, bribery, espionage, fighting in tournaments, trade agreements, asteroid mining for arguably the most valuable currency dilithium, among other tasks. These all net rewards which vary by the rarity of the mission, its difficulty, who's on it, and of course what the mission is in the first place determines the base set of rewards. You can even send one of your crew to be executed for incompetence as a Klingon, which even though its useless is just great to have sitting there as an option.The visuals are good, the game hasn't crashed once for me, the UI is customizable.All in all, a great MMO.

One of the best games I have ever played. Now let me explain why. I love...and I mean LOVE Star Trek, my fav series to be made on this planet we call home. Now the biggest reason why I love the game is because you not only get to be in the Star Trek universe and meet the shows Iconic characters. You get to side with one of the three series main factions. (Klingon, Federation, and Romulan) After choosing a faction to play on, you can choose one of the three classes. (Tactical, Science, and Engineering Officers) From here the story starts...you take a long time using the very well thought out character creation to make the best *You* in Star Trek as possible. From that you go ahead and start your missions in the main story. (Each faction will have there own beginning chapters and then it all comes together in the same story/missions) Do note that the Federation faction has a very slow and a little to long of a prologue chapter. Now as a new player that will be great, but I have played over 3.5 thousand hours on a non-steam client, and a few hundred or so on steam...till the steam client broke. Anyway, playing the game as much as I have. You get tired of doing that intro for the Federation over and over again. The plus side to this, they added the 23rd Century Federation as a new faction a while back. This being said you can not only play as a classic Federation character but play a new prologue to play and explore. As for the community. It is full of fun and Star Trek loving roleplayers. Yes roleplay is huge in this game, most if not almots all Fleets/Guilds will have roleplay be a normal part of the day to day tasks. With that said some Fleets will take it more realistic than others but still fun if you can find a Fleet that fits you. Adds tons of hours to the already great game. I have no idea if this review was helpful or just me being a Star Trek fangal...but I do hope it gave some light onto if you want to play the game or not. Anyway thank you for taking the time to read this review and do have a nice day/night.

as far as Free to play games go. this is the best mmo i've played so far (not really saying much since most are terrible) the character customization makes it so that you can have your character configured in almost any way you want, both their skills and their physical appearance. same goes for the officers, best of all everything is technically obtainable with ingame currency. there are some cons however. the ground combat gets very repetitive in the missions. but if you do get bored of the super repetitive missions, there is always the foundry. and the space combat is probably the best part about the entire game.in conclusion i think you should at least try it since it's free.

Such a great game, any trekkie fan will foam at the mouth when playing, the storylines are well written and the PVP/PVE is top notch, also the Lore of the game is well adapted from the the numerous tv series' a top top game for any star trek fans.For those just looking for space shooter that isnt EvE online, you've finally found what you're looking for, STO is much more immersive and action packed, (no spending 9 hours mining for minimal gain) the quests and storylines are better written and correlate with each other and tie in nicely with PVE raids and PVP battles.There is also a huge amount of customisability in this game, from a number of different starships, a number of different factions, Guilds, character appearance, character class, crew appearance etc etc (the list goes on and on)Truly a top gam, go and buy it right now!

A space MMO for fans and strangers to Star Trek alike, become the pilot of your own ship and explore a massive galaxy.I played this game for a little over a year when it first became F2P outside of Steam and then shelved it, but recently I have decided to make a new character and play through Steam to see what's new in the trek.Lots of character customization, tons of ships and equipment.. can become a bit grindy, but always events and daily tasks to keep you busy. Player made missions that can be very fun and free DLC 'Delta Rising' that adds lots of new content and missions.

If you like Star Trek and want to play a F2P game, this is a decent start to enjoy the story line/campaign. The universe is as real as it gets, you get most of all the iconic ships that the ST franchise ever designed and the alien worlds feel different from one another.So when it comes to just enjoying face-to-face what Star Trek feels like besides the scenes from the movies and series, this is a must play.However it completely goes over the top when it comes to end game like in any MMORPG...way too much fantasy stuff and made up stuff that is overly expensive to be enjoyable.Enjoy it as a F2P where you can explore the Star Trek universe, but be prepared to get lost when you start putting money into this game.

"The tomb raider reboot trilogy is one of my favorite series of video games. I started with shadow of the tomb raider and worked backwards to this game. The appeal of the tomb raider games for me is really about the progression of Lara’s abilities and weapons, and exploring the game world. I am going to try my best to think of this game as it’s own entity though, rather than a part of a series. Tomb Raider has always been about exploring ruins and ancient settings Indiana Jones style. The climbing and platforming used to explore those locations is really nothing special though, especially since the island you explore isn’t very interesting in terms of atmosphere. The game really shines with its puzzles and combat in my opinion. The puzzles are often inside of the tombs and ruins you explore, and everytime I get to one it always makes me think more than I would if it was just more climbing. The tombs might be the best sort of the game if you ask me, they give the game its identity and it wouldn’t be nearly as fun if they didn’t exist in it. The gunplay and combat is really fun, even if it is a bit on the simplistic side. Guns feel good to use, but show little impact on enemies. There is four guns, each of them feeling different from the others. The bow has kind of become a staple of the tomb raider reboot trilogy and it deserves that, it is probably the most complex weapon in the game. It feels good to one shot an enemy with a charged shot and it deserves to be recognized for being a truly fun and iconic weapon in my opinion. The last thing I want to talk about is the story. The story is this game is good, nothing more, nothing less. Lara is awesome as always, one of my favorite protagonists. Seeing her grow into the battle hardened killer she is by the end but still retain her curiosity and empathetic nature is really entertaining! The suggested relationship between her and Sam is really cute and I wish that we got to see more of it in the sequels. It’s a very cinematic story, it’s most memorable moments are those in which Lara is put into intense situations. We get to see her be vulnerable and it is really easy to empathize with her and just overall connect with her as a character. She grows throughout the story and it is exciting to not know what she’s gonna do after this adventure is done. I think that the strength of tomb raider has always been the gameplay, which is just as exciting as always, but this game surprised me with its engaging story and I loved it. If you have an interest in this game I cannot recommend it enough."

This game is very good, once you get used to the controls and play style. I give is around an 8.5 out of 10. Graphics could be better, yes, but this is an MMO, and for what it is, I think they've done quite well with it. I love the pre- and post-warp cutscenes and the transporter animations most, and some of the storyline talking cutscenes the least.The free to play part is a plus, too. It's a quality game, definitely, and doesn't simply lock you out of portions of the game just because you're free to play while others are premium, in fact, with enough effort, I'm sure you could accumulate enough dilithium to trade for substantial amounts of the premium in-game money (zen), which you can then use to buy the bigger, better, shinier, more premium things in the game.On a personal note, I'm happy with the game, and I'll be happy to continue playing. The best part is, once I tire of Federation quests (if I do), I can just make another character and experience Klingon or Romulan quests (you have more than enough character slots to make characters for each side). I think it's great that there isn't an entire side locked up for premium/paying users' use only, I think (though some races -- like the Joined Trill -- are locked up).Being free to play, I feel perfectly safe suggesting this game to anyone. If you don't like it, all you have to do is stop playing, because you didn't have to spend money on the game in the first place!
"this is the game you remember"

I had a lot of fun with this game, and I never paid anything but my time. If you are a Star Trek fan, you have nothing to lose, and you'll probably enjoy what they've done with the franchise and your personal story. I was tempted to buy cosmetic upgrades because I am a nerd ("Ooh they have Kirk's jacket from Wrath of Khan! I want it!"), but I never felt like I had to pay in order to win. You definitely CAN - you can pay real money to buy upgraded ships with special technology - but I never felt pressured to do so.I really like the crew management element of the game - essentially, the special abilities of your ship are determined by your bridge officers. Bridge officers can be requisitioned from Starfleet or acquired on missions, which I thought was a nice touch. You can customize your bridge officers appearances in a very satisfying way, from their appearance and uniform to their stance. I got a boring Trill medical officer and made him much more interesting by making him twitchy and neurotic. Once you've customized a uniform for yourself or an officer, it's easy to save the outfit and apply it to whoever you want.The rest of your crew - rank and file - are mostly just pegs you can shuffle around to complete timed tasks and projects, with a variety of little rewards. I enjoyed this 'Starfleet Spreadsheet Simulator' in kind of a perverse way, sending my little dudes to formulate warp bubble theories and whatnot, but it's mostly a time-waster.The main problem with the gameplay is this: the ship-to-ship combat is much more polished than the away missions, but away missions are where you will spend most of your time. The on-foot sections of the game have very awkward and inconsistent level design. If I could delegate those bits to my redshirts, I would mostly do it, and enjoy the game more.I put it down when I didn't feel like playing it anymore, and I haven't picked it up again since, but I enjoyed the time I spent playing it. It didn't feel addictive or manipulative.tl;dr : Try it if you like Star Trek. It's actually free and not fee-to-pay.

I loved playing this game.  My only gripe is that it crashes now pretty much consistantly at the loading screen.  If you can get passed the loading screen and you REALLY like Star Trek then I would recommend it.  It is NOT for fans of MMOs as it is HEAVILY Star Trek based and is not really a very good MMO.  It is an ok game, but a lousy MMO.  The missions are repetitive.  The AI is pathetic.  The story is laughable.  Still it is typical of a Star Trek game.  In other words, it is really only for the few remaining fans of Star Trek who haven't been scared off by the reboot movies.

"The first Tomb Raider game I didn't finish and just uninstalled. Long cutscenes, Lara constantly slowing down to fit through some narrow passage or walking like a snail to talk to her guy. It was really boring for me, apart from puzzles maybe."

as a star trek game, there is none better (sad reality is that it's true). space combat is done very well, ground, not so much.several endgame events to keep people busy, especially if you focus on the space ones.the only real downside i find to this game is Perfect World Entertainment. their business model for a F2P game, makes it more of a Freemium game. all the new stuff that is added to the game is added to the ZEN store (premium currency).they do update the game with new episodes and story arcs but the ships worth having are only obtainable by buying them with Zen.before cryptic was bought out the game had alot of potential as a subscription based MMO but as with most MMO's these days it went F2P and microtransactions everywhere.i am recommending it solely for the work Cryptic has done.

"Remaster my ass. Just putting a fresh coat of paint on it doesn't make it better. The game still has its bugs. More in the remaster than it had in the original. For a game advertised for stealth it's absolutely shit at it. Often it would alert enemies who aren't even paying attention and had no reason to look towards me.

And, often, the optional objectives would bug out after reloading a checkpoint (which most of the times takes you to the start of the mission) so it becomes impossible to complete it. I have played the original and I have gotten full sync in all the mission in it. But I give up in the remaster.

I had gotten this game with Odyssey. I had paid the extra bucks because I was getting 3 games for the price of one, and as good as Origins and Odyssey have been I had hoped they had done a good job fixing up AC3. But I'm sorely disappointed."

"The game that made a spectacular return of the greatest videogame heroine of all time.
A sensational reboot of Lara Croft into the gaming world. This game is an action packed thriller with explosive set-pieces and a storyline to root for.
The Lara Croft we know is absent. Long gone the duel wield weaponry and the unbeatable killer machine of a women we love, instead we get a timid and frightened young lady who is stranded in a japan-ish bermuda triangle.
Hunting for her life are the fanatics led by an intriguing character named Mathias who wants to resurrect the fabled Sun Queen who used to rule the world ages ago. However, Lara is not alone in her journey, she has her mentor & friend along with her best friend Sam and a group of rag tag explorers. 
The atmosphere is beautiful and horrific at the same time. Equally, gorgeous is the lead heroine Lara, who instead of over-sexualized in previous games, is depicted as an average explorer who when faced with the mortal dangers quickly sprangs into action. Camilla Ludington the voice of Lara has done an amazing job!
The puzzles are few but very intelligent and realistic, Lara dont have to push a button to solve everything like in past, here she has to manipulate surroundings in order to solve the puzzles.
This game is amazing, I have already played in 4 times and yet havent explored everything. After playing its sequel (Rise of Tomb Raider) and the series finale (Shadow of Tomb Raider) I conclude that this one is by far the most superior of the trilogy.
For Lara worshipper like me it was a mandatory game to play, however I would encourage every action/adventure lover out there to try this amazing masterpiece."

Pretty damn good. Great customization, fun gameplay both on ground and during epic spaceship battles, immersive zones, friendly community, better quests than the average mmo, packed with lore and readable stuff.If you like Star Trek then you will enjoy this game and if you have no clue about Star Trek you will still enjoy this game.

So right off the bat, I'm going to make the claim that if you're a Star Trek fan, you'll find something to love about this game.Whether it's the episodic campaign that draws heavily upon the series and films. Or the vast overworld that allows you to beam down to many of the iconic locations you've come to know and love, such as Deep Space Nine, Starfleet Academy, Earth Stardock, Risa, and, taken directly from the most beloved film of the series, Paradise City from ST V. (Kidding.) Or just being able to run around your own ship or shuttle, most of which are inspired by, or are of the same class as, the ones from the show/films, and pilot it around the galaxy. There's something in this game for everyone.Since most people here have already covered the big parts of the game, I'll point my own personal list of Pros and Cons:PROS:- Fantastic Campaign: The devs for STO are big time Trek fans, and you'll definitely discover this once you start making your way through the campaign of your choice: Starfleet, Romulan, or Klingon. Each episode is formatted like an episode of the show, most of which are heavily inspired by plotlines from the show and films. Some of the episodes even continue the stories of some ST characters. Some devolve into shoot-'em-ups, but most -- especially the recent ones -- are 100% Trek, on par with the show. There are also player-created missions available to play through by way of the Foundry, which is awesome and something I wish more MMOs would incorporate.- Frequent Updates: Cryptic update the game with major episodic content a few times a year, most of which have featured actors reprising their roles from the series, such as Michael Dorn (Worf), Tim Russ (Tuvok), and Denise Crosby (Tasha Yar). Leonard Nimoy also narrates many key parts of the game in-character as Spock. Each new episode has added new story content, dailies, and general updates -- and all of them have been free. We've had one full-fledged expansion, Legacy of Romulus, and another one on the way in October called Delta Rising.- The Star Trek Experience: A lot went into making the game feel like a genuine Trek experience. The general atmosphere, the scale of the overworld, the missions, the visuals, locations, and characters. You take command of your own ship, and you can pretty much roll up any character you can imagine: from the stock races, such as Human, Vulcan, Romulan, Klingon, Betazoid, Trill, Orion, etc., to a custom alien race that you can define. There are also a lot of RP opportunites: Dabo(!), asteroid mining, ship interiors, and seasonal events. Just a lot of great stuff.- F2P Model: If I had to make a list of the most ethical F2P MMOs on the market... it would be a short list, but STO would be near the top. All of the story, PvE, and PvP content is free, as are all the updates. Most of the things Cryptic are making money off of are cosmetic items (uniforms, ship interiors/exteriors), ships (but the free ships are just as competitive), and services like inventory space, character slots, bank space, etc. The two things that I would count against it are the lockboxes, which can be easily ignored, and the two races locked behind a paywall, though with nearly infinite races available to you, it doesn't make much of a difference in my opinion. With a model like this, I've been happy to support it since I started playing.KHANS:- Sector Space: Initially, it's no big deal, but after some time you start to realize how unintuitive Sector Space can be, sectioned off the way it is. Can you land here, orbit, or do nothing? Why are there invisible walls in space? There's an event here, but is anyone participating? What does the event even entail? Cryptic have stated in the past that they want to give Sector Space an overhaul, which would be awesome, but we still have it for now.- Instance Stagnation: There are a lot of PvE and PvP instances to queue up for. People play a select few, but most have stagnated -- not from lack of players, just lack of interest. I'd much rather them not be there if no one's going to play them, so that Cryptic would be able to put more focus on the ones people still enjoy.- Community: Do yourself a favor and find a good fleet that you can get along with, because the community in STO, at least the vocal part, might just drive you insane. This is nothing new to online games, but it seems abnormal in a Trek game. Part of the reason might be how fragmented chat is in STO, which makes moderation rather difficult. Making chat universal across individual sectors would make things better, I think, but for now reading ESD chat might just make you go blind.I think that about covers it! Like I said, if you're a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this a try, especially now that we're on the verge of a new expansion.Live long and prosper!

Confusing, Insulting to the player's general intelligence and overall daft.That sums up the entire game in a sentence. Upon entering the game, you create your character in a creation very similar to Champions Online, Allowing for a suitably enjoyable level of customisation.After creating your own alien race (or choosing from an existing, amazingly humanoid race) you are given the choice of choosing what part of the ship to man, which entirely makes no difference to the gameplay at all.Upon entering the world, you are thrust into a tutorial, that simaltaneously treats you as a moron, and sprays you with incohorent terms that only a diehard trekkie would understand, telling you the most basic of keys to move, while "forgetting" the more advanced you would need, but telling you to use an item with a ridiculous name that you spend at least a minute searching for on your interface.All in all, If you love Star Trek, give it a go, but prepare to be dissapointed. Elsewise, run away!

"A wonderful remaster of an already beautiful game. The assassin Creed series always did a great job of making the time period and cities within the best parts of their games. Boston and New York are breath taking. A definite step up in clarity from the PS 3 version and the frontier is absolutely teeming with life. The plants and dense forests are also presented in better clarity but not as much as the cities. The game plays the same with minor improvements to the mini map and ability to whistle from cover that has become a staple of newer entries to the series. Connor is still as brutal as ever. The tomahawk is the most brutal weapon introduced in any game including origins and odyssey and really shines here. Do yourself a favor whether you’re revisiting AC 3 once again or experiencing it for the first time clear your schedule and get lost in the beautiful recreation of the American revolution. You will enjoy every second of it."

Lifetime account, though my hours on Steam are lower... I tend to play direct from the game executable.  The game is a cash grab in one way... it has to pay for its servers.   I spend a little cash from time to time, but find my monthly stipend from the STO lifetime account (bought prior to release) has more than met my needs.  I turned off the notifications that others recieved this special ship or item long ago.  Ignoring them and buying only the ships I truly wanted to earning them through the various methods in game, by being selective I have always felt myself as able to play.  Yeah, they advertise to earn cash, but the game costs money to run AND they have consistently added new content and new voice acting to make it worthwhile.  Ah, I have admittedly bought the most expensive option of each expansion, but then again... it's paid back for the total time spent.  I expect that I have spent less than $15 a month to play and been quite happy to date.Yes, they add new stuff and its always to the players advantage, but thats how you keep it going, expanding, and paid for.  Give it a try, spend a little to help out the devs and enjoy.

I really liked the game in a lot of ways. I only did the single player campaign for a few missions before I quit. They're good, but not what I need right now and I hate trying to bind keys to work on a gamepad better. Sure, gamepad is great for Ryft, playable for WOW and SWTOR, and this one doesn't let down either. In fact, I'm getting old at 36, I'm just not for fine tuning and tweaking all the configs or macros. Let me start out by saying I love this game. I read the reviews and decided to pick it up on Stream, as it was free to play, and I was a big Star Trek fan. And it was great... at first. You can level really quickly, though part of that was due to the Delta Rising promotion they had going on when i joined, and the ships were great. Then I got to level 50, and was given access to the Delta Quadrant and Dyson Sphere. All the sudden, the wonderful mission's I'd been completing turned into 5-6 part grinds spanning over different areas, in different systems, in different sectors.... and I had one that I spent almost 2 hours trying to complete because even though I have the best ship in the "free" fleet, it does not match up to these enemies. So, unless I feel like spending money of upgraded ships and weaponry, I've gone about as far as I can in the storyline. I still plan on playing from time to time, but these missions are gonna be left undone, and my faith for future "seasons" highly in doubt.

"Every time I go back to give III another chance, I remember why it's terrible.
Haytham is great, and Liberation is actually really worth your time and it's a damn shame more of those features (and Avelline) didn't stick around. But the actual game of 3?

It isn't good. It was never good. It's story is anywhere between bland and motivated only by everyone involved being stubborn idiots (apart from when Haytham comes back, where the writing gets some life in it again thanks to him), as one of three people who really liked the Desmond story it gets so sidelined for what was blatantly supposed to be a focus at some stage in development... it's a mess. The 'cities' don't have the same fun actor to just run-around in as they used to, likely a result of them being frontier towns rather than bustling metropolises with narrow roofs, and while the tree running is nice it's not really used to all that great effect because it's easier and often times better to just get a horse and run along.
Anything this game did well, was done better by Black Flag. Everything this game did poorly would become endemic to the series.

I know Unity went through a renaissance of people saying it 'wasn't actually that bad'. Please, for the love of all that's holy, don't be fooled by a few hour long video essays or a new bad release into thinking III wasn't actually that bad. It was."

• Gameplay is somewhat repetitive and clunky.• The parts of the game that require you to interact with the UI are so confusing that after 20 hours of play and reading the beginners' guide on the official wiki, I'm still confused to the point of anger.• The universe Gene Roddenberry created was post-scarcity, where money no longer existed to divide people.  The irony of Star Trek being a "free-to-play" game is you're constantly reminded of your financial limitations in real life and confronted by players who can drop $350 to buy the DLC, and the vast array of upgrades available to buy in-game.

Been playin STO for a long long while "Bought it when it first came out" and I have to say that out of all the F2P models I have seen this one is one of the best. You can get whatever you want in the cash shop without spending a dime, you do this by mining and trading on the Dilithium market which is basically a form of currency that you can exchange for Cash Shop Zen. HOWEVER, be prepared to put in the time if you choose to go that route.  Biggest problem I have seen with this game is the players who actually play it. Those that dont put money into the game are constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing about the "advantage" other players have over them and Earth Spaceport has become a literal soapbox for these people to voice their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Despite the fact that if these people simply just put some time into the game they could have everything a paid player has access too as well. Putting money into the game is simply a time saving convinence, not a game breaking flaw. As many of these people would lead you to believe. Besides, there is a mission where you take a current generation Ship, slingshot around the sun, go back in time to TOS. And get drink recipes from Scotty... That alone should make you want to play. But, other than that the game is enjoyable and fun.10/10 Would go back in time to get alcohol recipes from Scotty again.

"A fantastic game with a brilliant story that really set the tone and foundation for future Assassin's Creed games to come. Despite how unfair it can be at times and how convoluted the plot later becomes (no spoilers), it is certainly an interesting journey with the variation of locations you are able to navigate in as Altair - a character I didn't originally particularly enjoy but found fascinating later down the line. Considering this is also an outdated and old PC port, some errors and mishaps are expected here and there. For example, whenever I accidentally tab out of the game in fullscreen because of my second screen, the entire game becomes windowed and I do not know how to fix it. Then again, it could be just my resolution.
Other than that, play this game! It's an experience. It will help you understand the lore better if you want to play more modern and advanced Assassin's Creed games anyway. In fact, I would even consider this more interesting and more fun than most of the modern titles Ubisoft pumps out every so often.

(PS. altair marry me)"

"So while the game is really good, don't get me wrong I 100% recommend this game, I do NOT recommend buying it from Steam, so the deal is it will work and start, first few times you install it, but it will hit an activation limit, and they will no longer reset the activation number, they had done this in the past for me, after contacting EA support, but I contacted them again to get reactivated and was told that they no longer would be doing that.

The process to get the game working through Origin was not a difficult one but it was rather annoying, I was asked for two forms of purchase, which was the receipt through Steam, and the email I received when I bought it, not too difficult right? Well I bought this game 10 years ago. And obviously didn't have the email, and they wouldn't take it, was told contact Steam support, which was super supportive, however they were unable to resend an email that old, for obvious reasons.

In the end I was given mercy from a customer service rep who activated it on my Origin with no problem. You might be able to activate your product key from Steam onto Origin (I was unable to even after I gave the rep my product key."

I have played this game since before its official release, and honestly if it wasn't for the fact it is the ONLY star trek game I would have left a long time ago.Even before the Delta Rising season, the grind was pretty intense just to get to decent equipment or event items.   After Delta Rising, there was a simultaneous heavy double-nerf where raids and queues were increased in difficulty by large measures, while simultaneously slashing queue rewards.The grind, especially after level 50 just to get decent equipment is huge and extreme and the rewards underwhelming.  Pair this with the fact Cryptic and PWE aren't able to clearly communicate even basic information to the user makes for a very frustrating experience for new users or users that expect basic competence from a development entity.The game is slowly dying, Delta Rising itself has seen a pretty big downturn in users, and most of the late game mission queues are never populated as they are too difficult to complete for the rewards.If you jump in, don't spend a dime on the game.  You are probably better off finding a new MMO with a more stable technology base.The fact I had to write a non-recommend for this game makes me sad.  It had potential, but all that potential was suffocated by terrible direction and management.

When I first saw this game I was like ok lets give it a go. Well after giving it a go I have to say they have and still are doing a great job. There tons to do even if you reach the max level you still get points to spend on your character which is cool. The daily events also help getting rare and important equipment. There are alot of fan made missions as well just in case you want to take a break from the main missions and if you are stuck then other players if you ask will be there to help but the mission will get tougher with the more players in the mission. Also if you like clans then there are more then a few to join. My dislike is that when playing as UFP that sometimes you have to do some past missions you already done just to level up to the level that it wants you to be to carry on in the game which was a let down. But other then that its the best Star trek Game yet and it gets better with friends.

This game was fun for a time.  Then, I tried to get my second ship.  I got a free token for another ship and went to turn it in and both the OK and CANCEL buttons did the same thing...nothing.  My token was gone and no new ship.  So, I played for a few days and built up enough Dilithium to purchase the Cruiser ship (15000).  I went to purchase the ship, my Dilithium disappeared and in the chat window it said I received the Cruiser, but sadly no ship.Granted, I was using a free account, but if free accounts are not allowed a second ship, why does my Ship Slots show 5 available and both my token and Dilithium were depeleted?  What's worse is the bug reporting system wouldn't let me notify the developers of this issue.  Shotty programming guys.  If you would have kept me happy on the free account, I would have became a paying member, but I don't think I want to waste anymore time or ANY money on this product.

"Remaster my ass. Just putting a fresh coat of paint on it doesn't make it better. The game still has its bugs. More in the remaster than it had in the original. For a game advertised for stealth it's absolutely shit at it. Often it would alert enemies who aren't even paying attention and had no reason to look towards me.

Always hated the Full Sync bullshit. They could have added more checkpoints. I have to keep restarting missions just because I missed some "optional objective" near the end of it. And, often, the optional objectives would bug out after reloading a checkpoint (which most of the times takes you to the start of the mission) so it becomes impossible to complete it. I have played the original and I have gotten full sync in all the mission in it. But I give up in the remaster.

I had gotten this game with Odyssey. I had paid the extra bucks because I was getting 3 games for the price of one, and as good as Origins and Odyssey have been I had hoped they had done a good job fixing up AC3. But I'm sorely disappointed."

If you are a Star Trek fan this game is a lot of fun. You get to captain your own ship and go on away missions. There is a lot of variety and things to do. This was my first mmo and I always come back to it when I am ready for some more trek experiences.

This is a great game for any star trek fan. I played it for a solid 3 weeks until I reached admiral level. From then on you are required to buy ships and equipemnet with real money if you want any chance to finish missons. So this means you'll get a good 50 hours gameplay until you have to reach into your pocket for mmo virtual products. So if your a star trek fan of any of the franchise give this a play for a few hours and decide after if you wan to spend money.The ship fights are great. The fan made missions are even better. The arrangement of your bridge crew adds fighting and mission abilites which is great. Complete customisation of your self crew and ship. The only downside I found was that every mission had you kill emeny ships. Its not very federation if your killing everything. The fan missions have a bit more of a true federation feel to them than the main ones. There is alot of fighting for a peaceful exploring space federation. Also its always updateing. If you dont update for a week itll be a good 10 min update waiting when you log in.

I only riecently integrated this game into steam and was playing for the first couple years from the stand-alone launcher, thus the relatively low hours played indication. But as somone who played that game from day one it is amazing to see how much this game has lived trough. The developers are really a group of dedicated folks. The game started out great in 2010 with some glitches of course. In seven years it turned into a even more amazing and enjoyable game. As a Star Trek fan I see it as an honor to consider this game as canon as the series and films. It is a pure joy to get immersed into a well crafted multy-arc story that will keep you on the edge of your seat for a long time. I really love this game!

"It's far from the best assassin's creed, but there is still plenty to like.

The biggest issues that people have, myself included, is that the game just isn't a great port.
All of the menus and functions were clearly made with a console controller in mind. I have played this way and the experience is far better. But that doesn't cover the limited options that haven't been improved in the remaster. So, as far as playing the game on PC through Steam, it isn't great.

But this is still an AC game. There's lots of fun to be had sneaking up on people, getting into trouble, gathering the collectable items. Connor is a good protagonist, and the story is one of the stronger in the series for both ancestor and Desmond missions. 

There is plenty of exposition as to why Connor is going down the path he is, which you will either love or hate. The dual-prologues can be a little slow, and this often gatekeeps people interest in the game. They are a slog if you're not terribly interesting in the world or characters.

Overall, it has a place in the bottom third of AC games. Okay, not great, but with enough for lovers of the series to get by."

I've played over 200 hours of this game. There is SO MUCH to it. From the moment you create your captain you're at the centrre of a canon storyline, and the game doesn't fail to deliver. EVERY star trek fan should want to sit in a captain's chair though, and doesn't need me to convince them. There is a little something for everyone though. It may sound like a silly aspect to judge, but the single player value to this MMO is insane, which is rare. Weather you party up, pvp, pve, RP, farm, grind or seriously roam around to take the sights it's easy to find something to do. Not just for star trek fans, but as a trekkie obviously worth checking out. Pay to play aspects coupled with ruthless marketing take away from the enjoyment, though everthing purchasable with money is possible to farm or grind for - albeit very tediously. My advice, spend your time having fun with the game until you unlock the end game ships, save up enough game currency to buy keys for lockboxes in auctions and try your luck for high tier ships that way. I ended up purchasing a t6 ship as a reward for hitting the level cap with no regrets. Best:High level of customization and choice 3rd person gameplay while on planet is good, if a little generic. But space battle mechanics are AWESOME. Best space battles in an online game by far imo. Story and lore written in star trek canon, lots of interesting locations, characters and situations trekkies will recognise, but it's not necessary to be familliar with literally any of it in order to enjoyMostly friendly communityGreat graphics, music, voice work, UI, controls, tutorials and a very large, interesting world to exploreDifficult gameplay - not just a matter of spamming a rotation of class abilities-there are tactics involved.Worst:Dev support has left much to be desired, although just for things like gameplay bugs. Community support and store support are dependable. Frequent updates and patching - means more down time, more bugs. Unfortunately most of the updates are made to the store and are designed to make players want to spend money. This would not bother me if previous updates were more stable before attention was made to updating again. A bit buggy. Shouldn't have to explain this. Nothing that breaks the game, but I've had to restart missions enough times that I should probably mention it. Freemium. Hate this. I know it's the future but it takes away from the enjoyment for everyone except the people it exploits. If you don't let this get to you, and indeed it is not SO bad compared to other freemium games, the purchasable items are excellent and there is a large attention to detail and value. Before you purchase anything I reccommend unlocking the lvl 60 ships or higher first. Overall the game is not perfect, may have been better as a subscription game, kinda lost its soul a little bit because of in game purchasing - but the developers and community have managed to keep the game very fun despite the small hangups. The engine and mechanics in this game alone are worth checking out. For the record, this is the only MMO that I've held even remote interest in for more than 6 months. Long story short: It's free, fun as hell, and the main problem is that without spending insane amounts of time mining or spending real money you really can't compare to the players that do. If anyone who plays it and doesn't enjoy it wants their $0.00 back I'll happily refund.

This is one of those games if you:A) Lost a betB) Are intoxicatedC) Are terribly bored to where the next option is cutting off your fingers for entertainmentD) You like Star TrekE) You said "Its free, why the hell not?"

"This is my first 3A title and my first Tomb Raider game, so take my opinion with a grain of salt.
Pros:
+ Absolutely stunning graphics.
+ Lara Croft looks gorgeous.
+ Lots of cutscenes with very good animation and voice acting.
+ Cinematic gameplay with linear narrative.
+ Well optimised and has very few bugs (which are non game-breaking and disappear when reloading the save).
+ Intuitive control with a Xbox controller.
+ Well designed auto-save system. It even automatically saves mi-puzzle or after finding each collectible. So the penalty of death is only one or two minutes of retrying.
+ Four weapons to choose from. Bows are such a pleasure to use!

Pros or Cons, depending on your taste:
+ The player is very well guided. Some examples are given by the three next points.
+ "Survival instinct" allows you to see enemies, interactable objects, climbable walls, places to advance the story, and collectibles in your surroundings.
+ The world is mostly linear, so it is not too difficult to find your way through the map, even though the texture of objects from the same location is very similar and not that distinguishable. In fact, most of the time you just keep moving forward, which is the only possible direction because the other three is blocked by insurmountable objects. On the other hand, exploration is very limited since paths are mostly prescribed.
+ Puzzles are very light-weighted, including those in the optional tombs. Besides, Lara gives you verbal hints about how to proceed.
+ Metroidvania influence. Some places or collectibles are only accessible when you have the necessary gears. So getting new equipments also unlocks more ways to explore the map.
+ By well-balancing and interspersing puzzles, free roaming, action events, and cutscenes, the game keeps players engaged.
+ Depending on how much time you spend on collectibles, side quests, and option tombs, a typical first playthrough takes 10-20 hours. IMO, this is just the right length to avoid being dragging or repetitive.
* Your skills and weapons can be upgraded. You will be fully (or almost) upgraded at the end, even without much farming.
* Very few side quests.
- Quick-time events are such a pain, even on Easy mode. And some puzzles also require jumps with good timing.
- The plot is meh and contains supernatural elements. But I like the depiction of how Lara grows from a feeble lass to a strong and independent [strike]mass killer[/strike] tomb raider.
- You are still free to roam after the end. However, apart from collectibles and optional tombs, there are not much else to do, and enemies rarely spawn. The whole island feels empty, bleak, and lonely.

Serious Cons for completionists:
- Highly missable achievements that require a second playthrough to get.
- Tons of difficult-to-find collectibles necessary for certain achievements, some have no sense at all in the background setting of the game (I am looking at you, [spoiler]GPS caches![/spoiler]) some are even not shown on the in-game map.
- 30% of the achievements are related to the multiplayer mode, which is dead on arrival and not even available on MacOS.

Final words:
Tomb Raider is a great game. Its story, gameplay, design, characters, graphics, all go very well together to give you a leisurely enjoyable experience, even for newcomers to 3A action games. Provided that you are not a completionist, I would say that it is a no-brainer to pick up this game. Besides, Tomb Raider is the first title of the second reboot (aka the Survivor Trilogy) of the Tomb Raider franchise. It has modern graphics, aesthetics, and gameplay design. So this is also the right starting point for anyone new to the franchise.

PS:
None of the DLC is actually useful. So if you wanna save a few bucks, just buy the base game instead of the GOTY version."

When screenshots of the planned "Star Trek Online" game were first teased almost a decade ago, it looked like a simulator for living in the Star Trek universe, much like the original Star Wars online game experience before it got ruined by patches and so on. A true sandbox for Star Trek-ness. However, it was taken over by another developer, one known for making comic-like games and generally actionning and arcade-ing things up to the max. My heart sank, because my favourite Star Trek games before then were games that simulated life on board your starship of choice.Bridge Commander for PC was one of those games, I'd go back and download all the old Star Trek games now and then and play them just to see if any were good, and some were excellent. Another was the Interactive Technical Manual/Captain's Chair set of games, which made it so that you could walk through little 360-degree photograph simulations of the ships and learn all sorts of things about everyone. Also one game that gets little to no cred is the Elite Force expansion for PC also, which took the Star Trek Voyager game and made it so that you could explore the ship, mess with the systems, play on the holodecks, and so forth. It took a good 3 hours to push every switch, which isn't long, but it's a good slice of life if you want to experience a walking simulator about ST:VOY. Also the new VR game looks to have some of that spirit - maybe.Star Trek Online is the antithesis to all of that. There's no classic roaming about and taking in the scenery, no smelling the roses, and for some reason the corridors are ridiculously huge - all the bridges and so on are blown up to the size of small soccer fields, even the one for the shuttlecraft looks like a basketball court you could do laps in. It's inulting to me as a veteran gamer, since I'm stuck wondering - "what, are they expecting so many casual players who have never tried to play an online game before, that they had to make it so they wouldn't be frustrated walking into walls all the time? is it literally made for mentally challenged people?!" I've never seen a game put so much freaking walking space everywhere. The transporter pads which are supposed to be somewhat uncomfortable to stand on with 5-6 people are suddenly these huge affairs the size of a moderately-priced living room. O_o; smhNo, you could say that STO tries to bring back the feeling of Original Series Star Trek, with Kirk facing a new escapade each episode and generally the ships and life and so forth falling into the background. I used to despise the Original Series for being too fast and loose with ... well, logic itself, frankly. Sometimes, most of the time in fact, the things the crew encounters and their reactions to it make a lot of sense. But now and then there was just no sense to what they were doing at all, and what my mom calls "60s values" were everywhere - people getting angry for absolutely no reason, being "chivalrous" (almost mocking) towards female crew members, and so on. I've recently watched TOS in its completeness and I have a much greater appreciation for it now, I found the fun in it as it were. But even Roddenberry seemed to back off from the feeling of the original, considering the way that the early Trek movies became almost pedantic affairs about Shakespeare and philosophy and politics. I like those best I think, out of all the Trek stuff that's been created, but this game seems to mostly if not entirely abandon those principles in favor of BANG! BANG! Space cowboys to the rescue!The thing is, it works. The Next Generation, Deep Space Nine, and Voyager all seemed to want to be saying something more fun and action-oriented than they actually did, esepcially in the episodes involving scary new species or little special events featuring warzones. It's like there was this anxious little boy hidden away inside the hearts of the producers, and every now and then he'd come out and for several episodes we'd just have a general romp around the galaxy, with torpedoes blasting around and so on. That's where Star Trek Online shines. It takes the time period from those series and tries to make it work as a series of TV-style episodes, which are crystallized into about a dozen quest chains (yes, that's all there is in the game for my faction, but they are relatively long - several hours at minimum each, more like 12-20 hours for some). Want to see Denise Crosby finally getting some serious attention in any Trek franchise? Well, here her performance as Empress Sela is charming and impeccable.The difference between STO and the actual TV shows is that while some of the best story arcs in the entire Star Trek universe - all the 29th century nonsense, the Year of Hell characters, the DS9 take on the Mirror Universe, and so on - were mostly ignored after their individual episodes and two-parters, the creators of Star Trek Online took the most interesting and audacious ideas and expanded them into significant things which affect everyone on a daily basis almost. More fun, more action, more romping around, more crazy conspiracies and interesting intrigue than the shows were usually willing to do. If the original shows were vanilla-flavored, this is artisinal chocolate with jalapeno sauce. The difference between fan theories and the actual material, especially when it comes to Star Trek fans, is that the fans come up with intellectual extensions that make it cool for nerds but are impossible to justify when you're marketing to a general audience who are just expecting to turn on their television sets and get a decent story. This does the fun nerdy "footnotes section at the Memory Alpha wiki" stuff that hopefully you've wanted to see (if you're a Trekkie).I tend to love and play (and review!) games which are kinda poopy when taken as a chance to fulfill one's hopes and dreams about what a person can do in a virtual world, but are immensely enjoyable when played on their own terms. This is a game which is best played on its own terms. It tries to take the pre-reboot storyline and tie it together with almost everything that's ever been created in Star Trek.. happening all at once, in a coherent storyline. For the most part, the writers (who are these gods?) manage to tie a whole bunch of ridiculously contrived continuities from the creators into something much more coherent than it originally was. It might slip past you if you don't care about the plot or aren't paying enough attention, but seriously, this game turns BAD (with a capital B!) episodes from the TV shows into something that makes sense and can actually form a long story that ties in with others. Play it for the episodes and very little else, and you'll find a fanfiction-style work that ties things together with amazing detail.My only real complaint is that literally nobody plays the PVP anymore, as far as I can tell. Want to use that amazing new ship you bought for more than your own personal masturbation in the latest quest line to be released? Well, tough. Apparently enough people ruined it early in the lifecycle of the game that you just can't find anyone to play with anymore. The PVE Queues the game has, where everyone defends against the Borg or whatnot, are full 24/7, and an excellent way to level (you can get 90% to the level cap within 12 hours if you just keep running them!). However, the PVP queues are at zero, zero, zero, zero, zero for every match type, all day and all night, with little to no flukes where there are suddenly more people in them. There's just nothing. I really wanted to try PVP even if it sucked, but I guess it's back to living through some pretty interesting Star Trek episodes for me. :) Which is both a blessing and a curse, as is most of this game.Accept STO as the flawed piece of semi-trash that it is, and you'll find plenty of treasures within, it just might be best to wait for enjoying them until you're in the mood to appreciate something that might not be perfect.

"Assassin's Creed is the kind of game that I have come to expect from Ubisoft: a detailed environment, a game loop, and disappointing story. It's possible to have good storytelling in an open world. Arkham City did it, Saints Row IV did it. This game does not. It is essentially \"Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego\" set in the crusader states. You get a target's name, count off the required number of \"investigations\", and then catch (kill) him. While the targets have the potential to be interesting characters, unfortunately they are not developed or seen at all until it's time to kill them. So you are left with the protagonist, an assassin who gets grounded by his dad for bad grades. And some characters in the framing story who are actually rather believable, but rarely seen."

Star Trek Online (STO) is a solid MMORPG with tons of customization option for those who are willing to work for it.  It is not, however, a good Star Trek game.  For me, the main draw of Star Trek isn't so much the science fiction, which let's face it, is on the silly side.  It is the characters, the dynamics between the crew that makes it interesting.  In-game, however, crew members are treated as little more than equipment, so that personal connection is gone.  You gain the ability to customize your officers however you want, true, but you lose what makes them characters.Another problem of the game is the randomly generated sidequests.  Sure, it's fun to pretend that you are the star of your own Star Trek show, routinely investigating strange species, artifacts, and negative space wedgies, but the mad-lib style of quest generation means that after a while, all these quests seem to blur together.  So aside from the story quests - which are well done, by the way - none of the other content is memorable.The saving grace for these sidequests is the Foundry, which allows users to create their own quests and stories.  Sturgeon's Law is in full effect here; 90% of the custom content is lackluster, but the other 10% makes it worthwhile.While the game has problems that prevent it from being truly great, I would still recommend it for MMO gamers.  The universe feels big, the ship-to-ship combat is frantic but tactical (although sometimes you fight with the UI more than the enemy), and the amount of reference to the Star Trek shows can make Star Trek enthusiasts giddy.  If these sound exciting, that this is the game for you.

Do I reccomend this game?Lemme answer that with a question. Is the Pope a Catholic?I absolutely love this game. I mean, the graphics could use a tad bit of an overhaul, but other than that, it is absolutely amazing.Farming for levels to pass through the main storyline? Tch, forget that. Instead, they give you a whole freaking squad to support you in your endeavours, and each mission is specifically designed to level you up, so you need not worry too much about advancing levels. There are special ships, but they're not available straight off the bat, even with purchases, the ships and weapons are restricted by level, as are equipment and such, ensuring an almost always fair game (There are exceptions, but that's just because the other guy has a good weapon combo, not because they're OP.), and in group events, everyone gets a cut of the experience (Some less than others, either because the majority are high levels, or vice versa). You'll be so addicted to the storyline that you'll have a threatening dreanought before you know it!The storyline itself... It's just so addicting, anyone who's watched a Star Trek movie will feel like they're in one. You'll rise among the ranks relatively quickly, and getting through the main campaign is in no way a grind. There's always something new and interesting to it, and by the time you're done, you'll be begging for more. I've never experienced a more exhilirating storyline. If anyone, these guys should be getting all the money. They've made a game that's just in no way a bad game for those who dont wanna pay. So give them your money instead of wasting it on P2W games.

When reading this review, please bear in mind that I am reviewing the Agents of Yesterday DLC, not the full game.Star Trek Online: Agents of Yesterday is a brand-new DLC for Star Trek Online. It consists of 6 missions if you choose to create a character from the Starfleet of the 23rd century, and also about 4 other missions towards the middle of the game whereby you become a Temporal Agent.The storyline takes you to various different locations and various timelines, most notably: the JJ Abrams Timeline (or the Kelvinverse) where the U.S.S Kelvin was destroyed in battle (presumably). In this timeline, you assist the U.S.S Yorktown against Na'Kuhl Raiders who are trying to destroy the timeline hence creating a weapon against the Federation. There are several ships added in his DLC, all of which, however, cost REAL MONEY. I have to say, however, that they are very unique and powerful although I am surprised at the lack of a Kelvin Timeline Constitution Class (T6). The DLC itself feels and looks very much like the TOS sounds and graphics I wanted but does not give me the option to change to the 2410 style later on when the TOS effects seemed to get slightly annoying, Other than this, it felt almost empty as the storyline ended abruptly. I feel that more could have been added to improve e experience.

Big, lore-heavy (and Lore light), and goofy. It's not the subtle intergallactic diplomacy styling of the TV shows; Star Trek Online takes more after the movies with more action and more conflict.This isn't a bad thing, the space combat has become more and more satisfying over the years and the complexity of situations improve every mission.The ground combat has improved enough to be fine, but isn't the most enjoyable part of the game. This is where the crew you bring on missions are helpful; they balance a lot of the quirks out and allow for some customization. In reality, if you take ground combat partially seriously it's alright and there's no real penalty for wiping on mission so the problems are ignorable.Since the game has been around for a few years, the ships available are many and wonderful. If you wanted to fly ships from the Dominion War perfect! Want to play a period-specific Enterprise from earlier shows and movies? They have that too. Everything comes with balance considerations, but careful outfitting and a casual play style make many of them servicable or at least different.

"Finished this game in a pirated copy before and finished it again on Steam. It still as clunky as ever. Maybe even clunkier - the game does not like frame rates higher than 60.

I like the story and characters though. It's the kind of cringe and edge I want in open world games.

If you are going to play this in 2021, enable v-sync because that will stop haystacks from killing you when you do a leap of faith (seriously). Also use the Steam Community Controller profile because this game does not have controller support."

I would recommend this game to those who enjoy space battle games, MMOs, or specifically Star Trek! The game contains a lot of elements I enjoy, lacks in a few areas, but mostly is a great game! I tend to take my time, with my own method of how I play the game, making logs for every mission I do. Like an actual Starfleet Officer would do, as far as I know. The whole Star Trek franchise is my 3rd favorite (set of) show(s). The games story throws me off, the Federation allied or has a peace treaty with both the Klingons and the Romulans, I don't know why they are considered enemies. Especially when the 3 sides that you can be on, don't really fight one another. I haven't gotten much into the campaign yet to really know and understand the story, but as far as I can tell, I just enjoy being able to be a Starfleet Officer and having my own ship, and of course making my own logs.Issues I have with this game:1. You can't customize your ship fully. You can, somewhat, but I wish there was a more detailed way to modify your ship.2. You can't change your first officers information. This kind of bugged me, I wish I could change my first officers details just as I can change my first officers appearance, but the game doesn't allow it.3. You can't train your officers in like a holodeck program, which I wish you could build your own training programs and have access to a holodeck program. That way you can train your officers and even earn experience for yourself, maybe?4. You have to buy a lot of things with no free way really to earn a few Zen coins every now and then.Other than the issues I have with the game, the game is really fun and enjoyable! Even for a MMO. Although having it a single player game would have been cooler, that way they probably would of payed attention to how you build your ship, or design your character, and all of that rather than focusing on how the PVP system will work. Like with most MMO's, you can't really summarize the story without going through most of the game. So I can't summarize the story for this game.

I have a Mac Pro (2013 model) - top of the line, but the Wine wrapper has enough issues that it doesn't do much but crash.  Lowering settings, replacing drivers, uninstalling/reinstalling - this is not a good sign for the game's future.If you're going to support a game on certain platforms, make sure it works on said platforms.Edit: I've spent the better part of two days trying to troubleshoot the issue.  This is common to have issues with Macs.  The Wine Wrapper doesn't commit a true scan on anything on your system when launching (for example, whethere I have an on-board graphics card or a behemoth, it doesn't care).  Again, for PC users - you might have a blast, especially for a free-to-play model, but I stand by what I said.

"Can't recommend. Game design is really not good. Cliche dialogues and cut-scenes every 30 second and it isn't possible to lower difficulty from highest mid game. So you need to replay all this cut-scenes from the scratch without ability to save game. And most short cut-scenes are unskippable.
I like hard games like Dark Souls or Sekiro but here high difficulty isn't fun, it is just annoying. 
Only way to lower difficulty is start again and see all cut-scenes from prologue again. Doesn't worth it for me. Don't want to see same cut-scene for fifth time. So I kept pushing. At last prologue is finished and after that I have ability to save at base camps. 
Another problem is controls on PC. Character doesn't always react fast enough and you jump sideways instead up... and start all other again. At least now I start from base camp and not from the beginning of the game.
Exploration is good enough. Battles are satisfying. But story scenes are mostly bad. I played other Tomb Raider games and didn't skip story scenes as I do here ... they are long and not engaging. In my opinion something go wrong with this game. Maybe change of dev team are to blame. "

"The woman said to the serpent, “We may eat fruit from the trees in the garden, 3 but God did say, ‘You must not eat fruit from the tree that is in the middle of the garden, and you must not touch it, or you will die.’”

4 “You will not certainly die,” the serpent said to the woman. 5 “For God knows that when you eat from it your eyes will be opened, and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”

6 When the woman saw that the fruit of the tree was good for food and pleasing to the eye, and also desirable for gaining wisdom, she took some and ate it. She also gave some to her husband, who was with her, and he ate it. 7 Then the eyes of both of them were opened, and they realized they were naked; so they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves.

8 Then the man and his wife heard the sound of the Lord God as he was walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and they hid from the Lord God among the trees of the garden. 9 But the Lord God called to the man, “Where are you?”"

"Shadow feels immense, engrossing, and beautiful, but also endlessly frustrating and confusing. The most fun was watching the story unfold like a movie, with little to no contribution by myself, and that story was excellent, but game play was more often a great chore than enjoyable.  As someone who loves the series, this was a disappointing last chapter.  Perhaps I should have played with the game at a greater difficulty level for the puzzles, but  they ended up been very simple, and yet, genuinely impossible to complete on the first try, or even the first few tries.  Many times it was incredibly difficult just to figure out what was happening.  Even when Lara would, in English, tell me what to do, I couldn't understand it.  In the most Tomb Raider moments, when Lara has to perform miraculous feats, the game was ruined by long series of chained tasks that had to be performed expertly, even though it wasn't possible to tell what tasks were required most of the time.  This was consistent throughout the game; and there was always at least one task chain that could not be foreseen without dying, as the mode of failure was the only clue that what Lara did was incorrect. The whole time, it felt like I was accessing scripted actions with my key presses, not actually using or improving my skill.  Combat was also inferior to previous chapters, requiring active choices in skill building which didn't lead to a unique build anyway.  I know this sounds like a common complaint about TR, and I experienced similar feelings about the TR reboot two releases prior, but it was not nearly this bad; that game succeed where this game fails. And they never figured out how to do the map feature properly. Were it not for the gorgeous scenery and truly enjoyable story, there would have been nothing to the game at all."

A game you genuinely have to spend your entire life grinding unless you cough up a small fortune. So if you are a retired star trek fan waiting to die in an old folks home with a few years to burn this is the game for you. Alternatively you can pay hundreds of Â£ obtaining everything only to find the only reason you were playing was to grind. I would recommend doing something else.

One of the best character creation systems out there for an MMO. Your ship can also be visually customized, albeit to a more limited degree than your character.You can customize your bridge officers in the same manner as your main character.The PvP aspect of the game has died down a lot over the years, so if you love PvP you'll might want to check elsewhere.Ground combat can be clunky most of the time, the missions get repetitive and follow; Space Combat, Space Combat, Ground Combat and SPace Combat. Very rarely does it migrate from this grind type.The game is a grind for end game, for all of you fanatics that love specialized loadouts to kill a certain type of enemy.Plenty of weapons to choose from for both ground and space.There are some ships that are carriers with a small amount of hangar bays.It has a lot of things that Star Wars:The Old Republic seriously lacks.It's a great game for Star Trek fans, this game follows the normal timeline with some excursions to other parts of time, or other universes.The community has some elitists but for the most part let you be. The customer service is great.The interiors of most places are extremelty large to what they should be.

"A fantastic game with a brilliant story that really set the tone and foundation for future Assassin's Creed games to come. Despite how unfair it can be at times and how convoluted the plot later becomes (no spoilers), it is certainly an interesting journey with the variation of locations you are able to navigate in as Altair - a character I didn't originally particularly enjoy but found fascinating later down the line. Considering this is also an outdated and old PC port, some errors and mishaps are expected here and there. For example, whenever I accidentally tab out of the game in fullscreen because of my second screen, the entire game becomes windowed and I do not know how to fix it. Then again, it could be just my resolution.
Other than that, play this game! It's an experience. It will help you understand the lore better if you want to play more modern and advanced Assassin's Creed games anyway. In fact, I would even consider this more interesting and more fun than most of the modern titles Ubisoft pumps out every so often.

(PS. altair marry me)"
